content:
• Thursday, March 2, 2017
  • DISH

    Sling TV to start offering NBC regional sports nets

    • Sling TV (DISH -1.9%) will begin streaming NBC (CMCSA -0.4%) Regional Sports Networks in some markets.
    • Starting later this month, eligible Sling Blue customers will get access to NBC's CSN California, CSN Bay Area, CSN Chicago and CSN Mid-Atlantic.
    • That will add baseball games to those that Sling customers can already get through national feeds and other regional sports nets from Fox and YES Network, in time for the sport's Opening Day.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:12 PM
  • ADSK

    Autodesk -1.8%; Q4 2017 over expectations, forecasts off

    • Q4 2017 results – revenue $478.8M (-26.1% Y/Y, $5.25M above estimates), EPS -$0.28 ($0.06 above estimates), new model subscriptions 1.09M (+227K Q/Q), total subscriptions 3.11M (+154K Q/Q), new model ARR $529M (+107% Y/Y), total ARR $1.6B (+16% Y/Y), deferred revenue $1.79B (+18% Y/Y), total spend $560M (-4% Y/Y)
    • Q1 2018 projections – revenue $460M-$480M (consensus $496.65M), EPS -$0.27 to -$0.21 (consensus -$0.13)
    • FY 2017 projections – revenue $2B-$2.05B (consensus $2.16B), EPS -$0.73 to -$0.56 (consensus -$0.11), spend approximately unchanged, net subscription additions 600K-650K, total ARR 24%-26%
    • After hours – (NASDAQ:ADSK) $85.75
    • Press release / conference call / 8-K
     
     
     
     
    | 6:39 PM
  • EVC

    Entravision +12.6% as revenues, profits rise

    • Entravision Communications (NYSE:EVC) has jumped 12.6% in after-hours trading following Q4 earnings where profits were in line, though revenues rose in all segments and the company entered a deal to buy a marketing solutions firm.
    • Entravision has a definitive deal to acquire Headway, a provider of "mobile, programmatic, data and performance digital marketing solutions" focused on the Western hemisphere, for cash on hand.
    • EBITDA rose 10% to $20.6M, which missed an expected $21.6M. Free cash flow rose 10%, to $14.92M, and net income was up 21% to $7M.
    • Revenue by segment: Television, $43.4M (up 9%); Radio, $20.2M (up 4%); Digital, $6.67M (up 6%).
    • The company anticipates about $264M in proceeds for its participation in the FCC's reverse spectrum auction, which it expects to receive in the second half.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 6:37 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers: HABT +6.5%. GFI +3.0%. GWRE +2.7%. SDLP +2.3%. IAG +2.1%.

  • IMMR

    Immersion -15.8%; Q4 2016, outlook disappoint

    • Q4 2016 results – revenue $9.3M (-43.9% Y/Y, $1.36M below estimates), EPS -$0.27 ($0.09 below estimates), royalty and license revenues $8.9M (-43% Y/Y), net loss $7.9M (vs. $2.1M net income Y/Y)
    • Outlook commentary (CEO Vic Viegas) – "In the near-term, we recognize that there will be some trade-offs with regards to financial performance as we vigorously defend our IP. In addition to normal considerations, our guidance for 2017 takes into account the ongoing litigation with Apple and the current unlicensed status of Samsung."
    • FY 2017 projections – revenue $38M-$42M (consensus $54.11M), EPS -$1.05 to -$0.76 (consensus -$0.15)
    • After hours – (NASDAQ:IMMR) $9
    • Press release / conference call / 8-K
     
     
     
     
    | 5:29 PM
  • RGLS

    Regulus loses $20M in Q4; HCV candidate RG-101 to remain on clinical hold until at least year end; shares ease 5% after hours

    • Regulus Therapeutics (NASDAQ:RGLS) loses $20M in Q4, cash balance at $76.1M (-34.0%).
    • Pipeline update:
    • Phase 2 study of RG-012 in Alport syndrome modified to include HERA study in 30 patients with rapid renal function decline. Top-line data from renal biopsy study expected in Q4, interim data from HERA expected in mid-2018.
    • Top-line data from the Phase 2 study of HCV candidate RG-101, in combination with Harvoni, Olysio or Daklinza, showed significant virologic response through 48 weeks of follow-up (genotypes 1 and 4). RG-101 + Harvoni showed a 100% cure rate (SVR48), RG-101 + Olysio showed 77% and RG-101 + Daklinza showed 84%. The results do not appear to demonstrate a clear treatment benefit from RG-101 compared to the companion therapies alone, however.
    • The clinical development program for RG-101 remains on clinical hold. The company expects to submit the requested data to the FDA in Q4.
    • Shares are down 5% after hours on light volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:01 PM | 5 Comments
  • MRVL

    Marvell Technology Group +1.8%; Q4 2017, forecasts positive

    • Q4 2017 results – revenue $571.4M (-7.3% Y/Y, $3.76M above estimates), EPS $0.22 ($0.03 above estimates), gross margin 57.6%, cash and short-term investments $1.67B
    • Q1 2018 projections – revenue $570M (+/- 2%; consensus $545.54M), EPS $0.19-$0.23 (consensus $0.17), gross margin 59%, operating expenses $250M-$265M

  • BLDR

    Builder FirstSource backer selling shares

    • The company launches a secondary offering of 10M shares to be sold by JLL Building Holdings. After the sale JLL will own 14.3M shares of BLDR.
    • The sale comes after a 38% gain YTD, and a near-doubling in the stock price over the past year.
    • Shares were initially lower on the announcement, but currently flat in thin after hours trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:48 PM | 1 Comment
  • KPTI

    Karyopharm's lead product candidate flunks mid-stage AML study; shares slump 11% after hours

    • An interim analysis of a Phase 2 clinical trial, SOPRA, assessing Karyopharm Therapeutics' (NASDAQ:KPTI) lead product candidate selinexor in patients with treatment-resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) showed that the study was unlikely to show a treatment benefit over physician choice (PC) as measured by overall survival (OS), the primary endpoint.
    • Complete responders did show a substantial OS benefit over PC so these patients will be permitted to continue in the study as agreed by the company and the independent Data Safety Monitoring Board.
    • The company remains undeterred by the setback. It says it will continue developing selinexor in AML though investigator-sponsored trials in multiple combination regimens, including chemo.
    • Selinexor is a SINE (Selective Inhibitor of Nuclear Export) compound. It binds to and inhibits the nuclear export protein XPO1 which leads to the accumulation of tumor suppressor proteins in the cell nucleus which amplifies tumor suppression. It is also under development for the treatment of liposarcoma, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and multiple myeloma.
    • Shares are down 11% after hours on increased volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:41 PM
  • NTNX

    Nutanix -15%; Q2 2017 over consensus, outlook off

    • Q2 2017 results – revenue $182.2M (+77.4% Y/Y, $3.82M above estimates), EPS -$0.28 ($0.07 above estimates), billings $227.4M (+59% Y/Y), net loss $39.9M (vs. $30.9M net loss Y/Y), cash and short-term investments $355.2M (+175% Y/Y), deferred revenue $420.6M (+128% Y/Y), operating cash flow $19.8M (vs. $4.5M Y/Y), free cash flow $7.1M (vs. -$5.9M Y/Y)
    • Q3 2017 projections – revenue $180M-$190M (consensus $188.45M), EPS -$0.45 to -$0.48 (consensus -$0.35), gross margin 57%-58%
    • After hours – (NASDAQ:NTNX) $26.40
    • Press release / conference call / 8-K
     
     
     
     
    | 4:41 PM | 8 Comments
  • CBB

    Cincinnati Bell CEO retiring; Fox named to take over

    • Cincinnati Bell (CBB -3.3%) says its CEO Ted Torbeck will retire May 31, and has tapped Leigh Fox to replace him.
    • Fox will take over as president and chief executive on May 31. Torbeck, 60, will remain on the board and work toward a smooth transition of duties.
    • Fox joined the firm in 2001. He's currently president and chief operating officer, and has previously held roles including chief financial officer, chief administrative officer, and other financial roles.
    • The company also reaffirmed 2017 guidance for revenues of $1.2B and EBITDA of $289.1M-$300.9M, both in line with consensus expectations.
    • After hours, shares are up 0.8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:40 PM
  • COST

    U.S. sales steady for Costco, membership fee increase on the way

    • Costco (NASDAQ:COST) reports a 3% increase in comparable sales in FQ2.
    • Comparable sales were higher in the U.S. (+3%) and Canada (+8%) during the quarter, but fell off in international markets (-2%).
    • For the four weeks ending February 26 (into FQ3), comparable sales in the U.S. were up 5% and the total comparable sales rose 4%.
    • The company announces that it will push through a $5 price increase to new members on June 1.
    • Previously: Costco Wholesale misses by $0.19, misses on revenue (March 2)
    • COST -4.96% AH to $169.16.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:36 PM | 13 Comments
  • SCYX

    SCYNEXIS' IV SCY-078 on clinical hold pending investigation of adverse events in early-stage study; shares down 31% after hours

    • The FDA has informed SCYNEXIS (NASDAQ:SCYX) to delay the initiation of any clinical trials assessing the intravenous (IV) formulation of lead product candidate SCY-078 until it completes the review of all available pre-clinical and clinical data on the IV formulation. The clinical hold was instituted after three mild-to-moderate thrombotic events were observed in a Phase 1 study in healthy volunteers.
    • The company intends to meet with the agency next quarter to discuss the data and agree on subsequent studies.
    • Clinical trials, present and future, assessing the oral formulation of SCY-078 are unaffected.
    • SCY-078 inhibits an enzyme called glucan synthase. Its value proposition is comparable activity to echinocandins [e.g., Astellas' Mycamine (micafungin sodium) for injection] but available in an oral formulation and active against multi-drug-resistant pathogens, including those resistant to echinocandins.
    • Shares are off 31% after hours on robust volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:25 PM | 17 Comments
  • AOBC

    Margins improve at American Outdoor Brands

    • American Outdoor Brands Corporation (NASDAQ:AOBC) reports gross margin increased 140 bps to 42.5% of sales during FQ4. Analysts expected a mark of 40.0%.
    • The company says operating cash flow during the quarter was $48.2M.
    • American Outdoor also invested $33.0M through acquisitions in Q4 and paid off $25M from a line of credit.
    • Looking ahead, American Outdoor sees FQ1 revenue of $200M.
    • Previously: American Outdoor Brands beats by $0.11, misses on revenue (March 2)
    • AOBC -4.33% AH to $18.54.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:16 PM | 24 Comments

  • Brazil tumbles despite dovish central bank message

    • The minutes from last month's policy meeting (at which the benchmark Selic rate was slashed 75 basis points to 12.25%) show the central bank willing to speed up the pace of rate cuts if inflation and the economy cooperate.
    • The next meeting is in April, and most expect another 75 basis point move, but the probability of 100 is on the rise, says Goldman's Alberto Ramos.
    • The real fell, as did the Bovespa, -1.85%.
    • EWZ -4%
    • ETFs: EWZ, BRF, BRZU, EWZS, BZQ, BRAQ, BRAZ, UBR, DBBR, FBZ
     
     
     
     
    | 4:15 PM | 13 Comments

  • PRTA

    Prothena readies 2.7M-share equity offering; shares ease a fraction after hours

    • Prothena (NASDAQ:PRTA) commences a public offering of 2.7M shares of common stock. Underwriters over-allotment is an additional 405K shares. Price and terms have yet to be announced.
    • Shares are off a fraction after hours on light volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:05 PM
  • WTI

    W&T Offshore +10% after surprise Q4 profit; sees $125M in 2017 capex

    • W&T Offshore (WTI +10.3%) surges after easily beating Q4 earnings expectations while posting its first adjusted profit in at least eight quarters.
    • WTI says Q4 production fell 10% Y/Y to 40.3K boe/day (55% oil and natural gas liquids) but revenues rose nearly 11%, as the $30.83/boe average realized sales price was 24% higher than $24.84/boe in the year-ago quarter.
    • Looking ahead, WTI expects ~$125M in FY 2017 capex, far exceeding its 2016 capex of $48.6M on an accrual basis and $83.8M on a cash basis; FY 2015 capex was $230M.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:35 PM | 1 Comment
  • NAVB

    Navidea shareholders OK sale of Lymphoseek sale to Cardinal; shares up 29%

    • At a special meeting held today, Navidea Biopharmaceuticals (NAVB +29.3%) shareholders overwhelmingly backed the proposed the sale of Lymphoseek to Cardinal Health (CAH -0.2%).
    • Under the terms of the deal, Navidea will receive $80M at closing and up to $230M in milestones through 2026, with $20.1M guaranteed over the next three years.
    • Previously: Navidea sells Lymphoseek to Cardinal Health for up to $310M; shares up 5% (Nov. 23, 2016)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:35 PM | 58 Comments
  • RF

    Investors take some profits in financials

    • Satiated bulls are doing some selling today, with the regional banking sector (KRE -2.4%) being hit the hardest (it's still higher by 56% Y/Y).
    • With opinion about a March rate hike having swung in the past handful of days from "no chance" to "sure thing," it's probably not a bad idea to take some profits. There's still the February employment report to come (next Friday, not tomorrow), and a weak one could quickly dial back hopes for higher rates.
    • Regions Financial (RF -3.6%), New York Community (NYCB -2.6%), KeyCorp (KEY -2.4%), PNC Financial (PNC -2.5%), Fifth Third (FITB -3.3%), SunTrust (STI -2.6%), M&T (MTB -3.1%)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:23 PM | 5 Comments
  • SNAP

    Nomura, Pivotal Research negative on Snap amid trading debut

    • Analyst Anthony DiClemente (Nomura Instinet) sets Snap at Reduce, with a $16 price target, noting slowing rates of user growth and monetization, aggressive competition (Facebook, WhatsApp, Instagram specifically) and a valuation observed too expensive relative to present and future growth.
    • Issuing $10 target, analyst Brian Wieser (Pivotal Research) iterates similar concerns, among others (steep expenses and cash costs, "sub-optimal corporate structure," dilutive share issuances, lack of voting rights). Further: "Investors in Snap will be exposed to an upstart facing aggressive competition from much larger companies, with a core user base that is not growing by much and which is only relatively elusive. It has a promising and innovative advertising offering, but so far it is still mostly unproven and difficult to quantify its ultimate scale." Rates shares at Sell.
    • Snap (NYSE:SNAP) $25.06, +47.41% above $17 offering price.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:17 PM | 41 Comments
  • XON

    Intrexon shrugs off early-session sell-off after Q4 miss, money flow turns positive over advancement of multiple businesses; shares ahead 8%

    • Intrexon (XON +7.7%) is flexing some muscle as the close approaches. Shares reversed from an early morning sell-off after Q4 results fell shy of consensus but are now poised to finish in the green on almost triple normal volume.
    • The positive money flow is apparently being stoked by optimism over the company's advancements in its Oxitec, Okanagan and AquaBounty businesses. Key developments:
    • Oxitec: Large-scale mosquito production facility opened in Brazil. Commitment for site's egg capacity this year expected. Friendly Aedes project in Piracicaba expanded. Roll-out in Cayman Islands underway. Open-field trial of self-limiting Mediterranean fruit fly in Australia moving forward.
    • Okanagan: First commercial harvest of non-browning Arctic Golden apples completed. Commercial launch in selected North American markets to commence this fall. Management believes it could be a $1B business.
    • AquaBounty: Recently approved by a number of large distributors. Construction of first U.S. facility expected to commence this year.
    • Previously: Intrexon misses by $0.14, misses on revenue (March 1)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:15 PM

  • SNP

    Sinopec to spend $29B in upgrading four refining bases

    • China's Sinopec (SNP -1.9%) says it will invest 200B yuan ($29B) to upgrade four refining bases by 2020 to produce higher-quality fuels.
    • SNP says the total refining capacity of the four refining sites will reach 130M metric tons/year, or 2.6M bbl/day, while ethylene capacity will reach 9M metric tons/year after the upgrades.
    • The bases will make up 4% of the company's total refining capacity and 65% of its ethylene capacity after the expansion, SNP says.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:44 PM
  • CNQ

    Canadian Natural Resources +6% after cruising past Q4 estimates

    • Canadian Natural Resources (CNQ +6%) rallies after Q4 earnings easily exceeded expectations, and funds flow from operations rose to C$1.68B from C$1.38B in the year-earlier ago.
    • CNQ says strong production and record low operating costs are driving its cash flow, which it targets to exceed capex by ~C$230M (US$172M) per month.
    • The company says Q4 oil and gas production inched higher to ~859K boe/day from 856K boe/day, but average realized prices before hedging rose by nearly a third Y/Y for crude oil and 6% for natural gas, and Q4 operating costs were a record low C$22.53/bbl.
    • CNQ forecasts FY 2017 production of 550K-590K bbl/day of crude oil and natural gas liquids and 1,700-1,760 MMcf/day of natural gas, before royalties.
    • In its earnings conference call, CNQ said it probably is interested in shipping natural gas under TransCanada's (TRP +0.1%) new flat toll for its Mainline system, but it has not yet made a firm decision.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:32 PM | 4 Comments

    Trading halt on Stage Stores

    • Trading has been halted on Stage Stores (SSI -8%) by the exchange.
    • The Nasdaq halt code indicates that a news announcement is pending.
    • Earlier today a 13D filed by HMA Acquisition raised some eyebrows.

  • Gold's bull run on two-week breather

    • The metal dipped another 1.35% today to $1,233 per ounce, its lowest level in two weeks, but only a large blip on a bounce that had previously taken the price from $1,130 per ounce in mid-December to $1,260 in mid-February.
    • The decline comes alongside a fast ratchet upward in rate hike expectations, with even a Fed dove hinting that the next FOMC move is coming this month.
    • GLD -1.4%
    • ETFs: GLD, IAU, PHYS, SGOL, UGL, DGP, GTU, UGLD, GLL, DZZ, GLDI, OUNZ, DGL, DGZ, DGLD, GYEN, GEUR, UBG, QGLDX, GHE, GHS, GLDW
     
     
     
     
    | 2:10 PM | 27 Comments
  • KR

    Highlights from Kroger's earnings call

    • Execs with Kroger (KR -3.5%) say the company is open to M&A, but isn't actively seeking out a deal.
    • They also pointed to rising labor, pension and health care costs as drags on earnings, while noting pricing could work in its favor during the second half.
    • The company plans to increase its investment in digital in order to connect with customers. Early success with the online ordering ClickList is mentioned.
    • Kroger earnings call webcast
    • Previously: Kroger beats by $0.01, beats on revenue (March 2)
    • Previously: Kroger on the mark with profit guidance (March 2)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:03 PM

  • SUBCY

    Subsea 7 surges to four-year highs on Q4 beat, special dividend

    • Subsea 7 (OTCPK:SUBCY +3.9%) reported better than expected Q4 earnings earlier today along with plans to pay a special dividend, sending shares to their highest level in four years in Oslo trading.
    • The Pareto brokerage says strong project execution and the first dividend payment since 2013 helped to trigger the positive reaction; however, Bernstein analysts maintained their Underperform rating, saying Subsea 7's prospects remain uncertain even after the solid quarter.
    • Subsea 7 reported Q4 adjusted EBITDA of $288M, more than 50% better than the analyst consensus forecast of $187M
     
     
     
     
    | 1:55 PM | 1 Comment
  • HGG

    Best Buy rallies after hhgregg shrinks retail footprint

    • Retailer hhgregg (HGG) says it will close 88 stores as it looks to fend off bankruptcy.
    • "We are strategically exiting markets and stores that are not financially profitable for us," says CEO Robert Riesbeck.
    • Three distribution centers will also be shuttered.
    • Best Buy (BBY +6.5%) is higher in a possible reaction to the development. The retail sector is also having a solid day across the board.
    • Previously: Relief rally for retail stocks (March 2)
    • hhgregg press release
     
     
     
     
    | 1:45 PM | 12 Comments
  • KPTI

    Animal spirits continue in biotech

    • A trio of players announcing presentations of preclinical data at the American Association for Cancer Research in early April are among the sector movers today: Karyopharm Therapeutics (KPTI +23%), ImmunoGen (IMGN +11%), Affimed (AFMD +4.8%).
    • The IBB's 0.85% advance this session puts that ETF higher by nearly 5% on the week and 15% YTD. The XLV today is up marginally vs. the S&P 500's 0.4% decline.
    • ETFs: IBB, XBI, BBH, FBT, HQL, PBE, LABU, BBC, BBP, LABD, UBIO, ZBIO, LABS
     
     
     
     
    | 1:20 PM | 17 Comments
  • ETFC

    Online brokers decline after E*Trade joins rate cuts

    • While E*Trade's (ETFC -2.3%) move to slash commissions was expected given the big cuts from competitors earlier this week, what was at least somewhat surprising was the change to its active trading tier, says Wells Fargo's Chris Harris.
    • Just 30 trades per quarter are necessary for eligibility vs. 150 previously.
    • Ahead of the announcement, Harris had already reduced EPS estimates for E*Trade by 8-10%, and now he's cutting another two cents off to $1.83 for 2017. 2018 expectations are reaffirmed at $1.97, as is the price target range of $36-$40 (current is just under $36).
    • Harris: "While the price cutting moves that have occurred in recent weeks are a negative for e-broker fundamentals and the stocks, we are optimistic that there won’t be further wholesale pricing reductions at this juncture (as there are no clear winners from these actions)."
    • Schwab (SCHW -1.4%), Ameritrade (AMTD -3.1%), Interactive Brokers (IBKR -1.5%)
    • Previously: E*Trade joins competitors with commission cut (March 2)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:12 PM | 2 Comments

    Bloomberg: Air Methods in play

    • Air Methods (AIRM +11.3%) spikes on reports the company is receiving takeover bids.
    • Bloomberg News reports that KKR is in the mix.
    • Shares of Air Methods are at a 52-week high.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:06 PM | 2 Comments
  • MU

    Micron Technology +1.85%; Q2 2017 expected at or above high-end of guidance

    • Preliminary Q2 2017 results – revenue $4.65B (+/- $50M) [vs. $4.35B-$4.7B expected prior, $4.55B consensus], EPS $0.86 (+/- a few cents) [vs. $0.58-$0.68 prior, $0.66 consensus], gross margin 37.5% (+/- 0.5%) [vs. 31%-34% prior]
    • Micron Technology (NASDAQ:MU) attributes mix, cost improvements and pricing to the affirmative preannouncement, while noting overall demand health remains, and into Q3 2017, so do positive operational and market momentum.
    • Micron's formal reporting is scheduled for March 23.
    • 8-K
     
     
     
     
    | 1:05 PM | 26 Comments

  • Financials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 1:00 PM

    • Gainers: PMTS +10%.
    • Losers: AHP -11%. ARES -10%. FANH -9%. ZAIS -7%. NMIH -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:00 PM
  • TMUS

    Slowing T-Mobile cuts Deutsche Telekom growth forecast; merger more likely?

    • With expectations for slowing growth from its T-Mobile (TMUS +0.6%) arm, Deutsche Telekom (OTCQX:DTEGY -1.5%) is saying its core profit growth would cut in half this year.
    • As far as DT is concerned, that only builds the case for a U.S. merger that recently has the attention of Sprint (S -0.8%) owner SoftBank (OTCPK:SFTBY -1.9%). That company is reportedly willing to give up control of Sprint to DT in order to seal the deal.
    • With both parties seeming willing, it may come down to logistics and regulators. "Are we rather seller or buyer? It always depends on the quality of the possibilities," says Deutsche Telekom CEO Tim Hoettges. "I don't prejudge. We do everything from the point of view of value creation."
    • DT's EBITDA is expected to rise just under 4% to about €22.2B in 2017. T-Mobile US saw its EBITDA grow 29% last year and that's expected to slow to 7% this year.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:57 PM | 51 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: SNAP +48%. AUPH +38%. KPTI +25%. NVGS +24%. AMRC +16%. OASM +16%. NKTR +16%. ANF +15%. FFHL +15%. WTI +14%.
    • Losers: ADPT -46%. OTC:CALI -36%. RGCO -27%. OME -21%. EXK -20%. I -17%. PTCT -16%. SKLN -14%. VEC -13%. TIK -12%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:47 PM | 7 Comments
  • IMMU

    Activist investor venBio rejects Immunomedics' latest settlement proposal in tussle over control; shares up 3%

    • Immunomedics (IMMU +2.9%) is up on slightly higher volume on the heels of its announcement that activist shareholder venBio has rejected its revised settlement proposal ahead of tomorrow's annual meeting.

    • Caterpillar (NYSE:CAT) shares are 4.8% lower as federal officials search the company's headquarters and other area facilities, the company confirms.

    • An employee source says that some employees have been directed to the cafeteria and told to remain there.
    • Some officials entering the building had jackets with IRS logos, while others appeared to be from the FDIC, the Peoria Journal Star reports. Still others seemed to be tied to police from the Commerce Dept.

  • VALE

    Iron ore prices may snap back toward fundamentals, analyst says

    • Vale (VALE -5.8%), Rio Tinto (RIO -2.5%) and BHP Billiton (BHP -1%) are lower following a report from Axiom Capital's Gordon Johnson warning iron ore investors to prepare for a flood of new supply to come online in the next several years.
    • Johnson argues that the Chinese steel mill restocking cycle, the largest in more than six years, has contributed to the rapid rise in iron ore prices, but that steel inventory is peaking and iron ore prices will soon reflect underlying market fundamentals.
    • Johnson forecasts excess seaborne supply of iron ore will jump to 269M tons by 2020 from an estimated 37M tons in 2016, and sees iron ore prices of $60/ton in 2017 and $40/ton in 2018 from ~$91.30 currently.
    • Also, Reuters reports that surging iron ore prices may prompt Chinese producers to reopen shuttered mines, potentially tightening the market.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:10 PM | 18 Comments
